message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of nephrotic syndrome, which is characterized by massive proteinuria and edema. Diffuse capillary and basement membrane thickening suggests membranous nephropathy, which is characterized by a spike and dome appearance on electron microscopy. Effacement of foot processes is seen in minimal change disease. Subepithelial humps are seen in post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. Massive amyloid deposition and spicular aggregates are seen in amyloidosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and urinalysis are consistent with nephrotic syndrome, and the renal biopsy findings suggest membranous glomerulonephritis. Membranous glomerulonephritis is associated with the spike and dome appearance on electron microscopy. Effacement of foot process is associated with minimal change disease, subepithelial humps are associated with membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, and massive amyloid deposition and spicular aggregates are associated with amyloidosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of nephrotic syndrome and a renal biopsy shows diffuse capillary and basement membrane thickening, which suggests membranous nephropathy. The expected finding on electron microscopy in membranous nephropathy is a spike and dome appearance. Option A is seen in minimal change disease, option B is seen in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, and option D is seen in amyloidosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's presentation, urinalysis, and renal biopsy findings suggest the presence of membranous nephropathy. Electron microscopy of the biopsy sample would show a spike and dome appearance, which is a characteristic finding of membranous nephropathy. Effacement of foot processes is a finding in minimal change disease, subepithelial humps are seen in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, and massive amyloid deposition and spicular aggregates suggest amyloidosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation suggests nephrotic syndrome and the urinalysis findings support this diagnosis. Diffuse capillary and basement membrane thickening on renal biopsy suggests membranous nephropathy, which is associated with the spike and dome appearance on electron microscopy. Effacement of foot process is associated with minimal change disease, subepithelial humps are associated with membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, and massive amyloid deposition and spicular aggregates are associated with amyloidosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of nephrotic syndrome, including edema and proteinuria, and the biopsy shows diffuse capillary and basement membrane thickening. These findings are consistent with membranous nephropathy, which is characterized by a spike and dome appearance on electron microscopy due to the immune complexes deposited on the subepithelial aspect of the glomerular basement membrane. Option (A) describes findings in minimal change disease, (B) describes findings in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, and (D) describes findings in amyloidosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of nephrotic syndrome and a renal biopsy shows capillary and basement membrane thickening, which suggests membranous nephropathy. Electron microscopy of the biopsy sample would show a "spike and dome" appearance. Effacement of foot processes is seen in minimal change disease, subepithelial humps are seen in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, and massive amyloid deposition and spicular aggregates are seen in amyloidosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and urinalysis results suggest nephrotic syndrome, and the biopsy findings suggest membranous nephropathy. Subepithelial humps are characteristic of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis type 1. Effacement of foot processes is characteristic of minimal change disease and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. Massive amyloid deposition and spicular aggregates are characteristic of amyloidosis. The spike and dome appearance is characteristic of membranous nephropathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation, urinalysis, and renal biopsy findings suggest membranous nephropathy. Electron microscopy of the biopsy is expected to show a spike and dome appearance. Effacement of foot process is seen in minimal change disease, subepithelial humps in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, and massive amyloid deposition and spicular aggregates in amyloidosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting with symptoms of nephrotic syndrome, with high urinary protein excretion and findings of capillary and basement membrane thickening on the renal biopsy. This is characteristic of membranous nephropathy. Electron microscopy in membranous nephropathy typically shows a spike and dome appearance due to subepithelial immune deposits. Effacement of foot processes is seen in minimal change disease, subepithelial humps are seen in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, and massive amyloid deposition is seen in amyloidosis.
